box.text: in this example, you navigate in the direction the controller is pointing, at a speed depending on the trigger squeeze.
apply as motion to the navigation jit.anim.node. disabled easing to reduce nausea.
scale by trigger squeeze, and negate for a forward vector
get z axis ('backward vector') of controller, in tracking ('chaperone') space
relative to the virtual-world navigation pose
relative to the real-world tracking system (position in meters)
route tracked_quat tracked_position velocity angular_velocity trigger trackpad buttons
route tracked_quat tracked_position velocity angular_velocity trigger trackpad buttons
report battery status for each wand:
watch out for triggering lots of haptic events like this, it can wipe out the battery life pretty quick.

vibrate <hand> <intensity>, 
where <hand> is 0 for left, 1 for right, 
and <intensity> ranges from about 0. to 3.7
The htcvive object gives you the camera data as a texture, to keep things on the GPU for speed. bringing it back to the CPU (as a matrix) can affect framerate.
The camera will only work if it is also enabled in the SteamVR settings (under the Camera tab)
The Vive has a camera mounted on the front, which you can enable with @use_camera 1
Going in & out of fullscreen on Windows re-creates the OpenGL context, which can break rendering on the Vive. Sending a "connect" message rebuilds textures and fixes this.
output image to the jitter window
FSAA might make edges look softer, but also may impact frame rate
put all your world content in the "vive_world" drawing context
set position/orientation of world origin (e.g. for navigation)
Using the HTC Vive head-mounted display
